Emergency Response Program
Employees are trained to evacuate and call 911 in case of an emergency.  The Wilbur-Ellis Dixon Facility will coordinate with local Fire Department and First Responders.  The facility has filed a Business Emergency Plan to help coordinate with local responders.  An Emergency Action Plan (EAP) that meets the requirements of the CCR Title 8 §3220 is in place.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Wilbur-Ellis is in the process of developing a new site in Woodland which will consolidate two existing sites and allow the shutdown of the Dixon Facility in 2023.  The new facility will be in a less populated area and is being built using the best practices developed at Wilbur-Ellis sites. 
Since the previous RMP submittal, we have begun 
-	Implementation of a comprehensive Corporate Management System titled Guiding People to Safety (GPS). GPS consists of 39 discrete elements, including facility inspections, incident reporting and investigation, Job Safety Analyses, MOC, Stop work authority, contractor safety, Hot work, in addition to RMP.
-	Implementation of “Navigator”, our Enablon®-based management system data base being used for incident reporting and follow up, auditing, and corrective action tracking.

Accidental Release Prevention Program
As part of the implementation of CalARP Program level 3, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by the facility to manage process safety issues associated with the use of anhydrous ammonia.  Prevention elements for each program are listed in Table 1 below.
 
List of Prevention Program Elements 
Anhydrous Ammonia Storage Prevention Program 3 Elements
   -Process Safety Information
   - Process Hazard Analysis
   - Operating Procedures
   - Training
   - Mechanical Integrity
   - Management of Change
   - Pre-Startup Safety Review
   - Compliance Audits
   - Incident Investigation
   - Employee Participation
   - Hot Work Permit
   - Contractors

Five-Year Accident History
There have been no CalARP-applicable releases of anhydrous ammonia or aqueous at the facility in at least the past five (5) years.  

External Events Analysis
Pursuant to the requirements of CCR, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, §2745.7(q), general events external to the plant are addressed in the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) for the anhydrous ammonia process.  Specifically, the external events requirements were met with the following actions:
   1)	The types of natural and human caused external events considered in PHA §2760.2.  During the PHA, a broad list of external events was considered by the Study Team.  The external events that were considered credible include, but are not limited to, earthquake, vandalism, sabotage, external fire, human error/misoperation, and vehicle impact.
   2)	The estimated magnitude or scope of external events which were considered.  If not known, the owner or operator of the stationary source shall work closely with the Administering Agency (AA) to determine what is required.  If seismic events are applicable, the parameters used in the consideration of the seismic analysis and which edition of the Uniform Building Code was used when the process was designed.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Accidental Release Prevention Policies
The facility has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Anhydrous Ammonia Storage System.  The facility's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substance.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substance
The primary activity at the facility is the storage, and sale of fertilizers, in addition to, the sale of pre-packaged agricultural chemicals to farmers.  Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a crop production nutrient.  Anhydrous ammonia is received by truck and stored in one 21,800-gallon (gal) storage tank (bullet tank) at the site.   The Wilbur-Ellis, Dixon facility also stored up to 30 1,000-gallon nurse tanks that could contain anhydrous ammonia at any given time.  The facility implements administrative controls that limit the maximum quantity to 82 percent (%) of the fill capacity for both covered processes.  The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia handled in this process is 162,020 pounds (lb.) 

Hazard Assessment Summary/Offsite Consequence Analysis
Worst-Case/Alternative Release Scenarios Results Summary
Per CalARP Regulations, one worst-case release scenario and one alternative release scenario have been defined for each process.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation.  

Risk Considerations
Anhydrous ammonia storage and distribution has inherent potential risks to potentially reach sensitive populations within the community. The facility's identified potential risks for an ammonia release from its process are included in the off-site consequence analysis and Process Hazard Analysis (PHA).
